results.title: Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?
results.creator_credit: Mike Nichols, Ernest Lehman and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Nichol’s debut feature after a string of successes on Broadway retained the taboo-breaking profane and sexually charged dialogue of Albee’s stage play, the likes of which had not previously been heard in a big studio film. Burton and Taylor play a married couple in decline who engage in a relentless, vitriolic war of words over the course of one night in the presence of their guests. The film was rehearsed for three weeks before shooting started and was both a critical and box-office success, winning five Oscars. Cast: Elizabeth Taylor, Richard Burton, Sandy Dennis, George Segal.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mike Nichols, Ernest Lehman and Warner Bros Pictures

results.title: What becomes of the broken hearted?
results.creator_credit: Ian Mune, Bill Gavin and Sequel Productions
results.brief_description: It’s five years from where “Once were warriors” left us, and Jake the Muss has turned his back on his family - breaking old habits is not as easy. His long suffering wife, Beth (Rena Owen), has left him and is living with someone new. Jake too has started a new relationship which is punctuated by violence and alcohol abuse. He is reunited with Beth and younger son, Sonny (Clint Eruera), at the funeral of Nig, who died in a gang fight. Tensions flare between Jake and Sonny, and as Sonny delves deeper into the dangerous world of gangs to gain retribution for his elder brother’s death, Jake must face, once and for all, the demons of the past and open up to the possibility of change, and survival.

results.title: What's eating Gilbert Grape?
results.creator_credit: Lasse Hallstrom, David Matalon, Bertil Ohlsson, Meir Teper, J and M Entertainment and Matalon Teper Ohlsson Production
results.brief_description: From the acclaimed director of “My life as a dog”, “What’s eating Gilbert Grape?” is a moving and at times comic portrayal of an unusual family in a small town. Gilbert (Johnny Depp) must keep a vigilant eye on his family, particularly his intellectually disabled younger brother Arnie (Leonardo Di Caprio) and his reclusive mother. When a stranger (Juliette Lewis) comes to town, she not only captures his heart, but also turns his life around.

results.title: West Side Story
results.creator_credit: Jerome Robbins, Robert Wise, Seven Arts Productions and Mirisch Corporation
results.brief_description: America, “Tonight”, “Maria”, “Somewhere”, “I Feel Pretty” - just some of the sensational evergreen songs from “West Side Story”, the winner of ten Oscars including Best Picture. Opening with the now famous helicopter shot of Manhattan, “West Side Story” is the heart-rending, brilliantly tuneful contemporary version of “Romeo and Juliet”. The gang rivalry between The Jets and the Puerto Rican Sharks reaches fever pitch when ex-Jet Tony falls in love with Maria, the sister of Shark leader Bernardo. When Bernado is killed in a gang misunderstanding, Tony and Maria become the unwilling, tragic participants in the resulting vendetta. Music by Leonard Bernstein. Starring Natalie Wood as Maria, Richard Beymer as Tony, Russ Tamblyn as Riff and Rita Moreno as Anita. Based on the book by Arthur Laurents.

results.title: Welcome to Woop Woop
results.creator_credit: Stephan Elliott, Finola Dwyer, Unthank Films, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Scala Productions
results.brief_description:
Directed by Stephan Elliott, “Welcome to Woop Woop”, was the follow-up film after his smash hit “Priscilla, Queen of the desert”. A black comedy, the film is a satire on the great mythical Australian outback and the people that are said to inhabit it. The film is populated by unsavoury characters, who dress and act repulsively and speak in a crass and offensive dialogue, littered with ockerisms and bush slang. Teddy, a New York con artist flees America and goes on the lam in Australia. Once there is seduced by the sexually voracious Angie and taken to her hometown of Woop Woop where he is effectively imprisoned by the law of Daddy-O, Angie’s tyrannical father. Amongst other eccentric behaviours, the town folk gather nightly to watch “The Sound of music” and “South Pacific” played on a loop at the local drive-in. Elliot confounds viewer expectations offering up more extreme and vulgar outback personalities than could possibly be imagined, making these characters repugnant to watch. The film slyly sends up films such as “Crocodile Dundee” which pandered to the gross stereotypes that so appealed to audiences. Elliot however failed to appeal to anyone with this bizarre and subversive flick, receiving critical brickbats and woeful box office returns.
Cast includes: Johnathon Schaech, Rod Taylor, Susie Porter, Richard Moir, Maggie Kirkpatrick, Barry Humphries and Paul Mercurio

results.title: Welcome to the dollhouse
results.brief_description: Todd Solondz’s debut feature is a darkly funny and bleak tale of the trials and horrors of high school outsiders. “Welcome to the Dollhouse” exacts with excruciating and all too familiar detail the ritualistic and cut throat pecking order of a New Jersey high school. In the title role Solondz has found an unusual alter ego in eleven year old Dawn Wiener (Heather Matarazzo), whose thick glasses, social awkwardness and infantile dress sense have marked her with the cruel nickname of Wiener dog. This has made her into the prime target for every high school bully including Brandon (Brendon Sexton the 3rd), a vicious delinquent who is constantly threatening to rape Dawn after school. Brandon’s promise of sexual assault become one of the many obstacles Dawn must deal with in her unrelenting journey through puberty, along with unsympathetic parents, a younger prissy sister that is unbearably wholesome, and a painful crush on the dreamy school rebel Steve (Eric Mabius). Cast also includes Daria Kalinina, Matthew Faber and Dimitri Iervolino. (Awards: Winner of the Grand Jury Prize at the 1996 Sundance Film Festival)

results.title: Welcome to Sarajevo
results.creator_credit: Michael Winterbottom, Damian Jones, Graham Broadbent, Miramax Films and Channel Four Television
results.brief_description: Based on a true story, “Welcome To Sarajevo” is a rare example of the war genre, one prepared to indict the western world for its refusal to aid the victims of a modern warzone like the former Yugoslavia. British journalist Michael Henderson (Stephen Dillane) begins a series of reports on a Muslim orphanage where dozens of children are trapped without food or medical support. His reports become pleas for help and finally scathing editorials before he takes matters into his own hands. Director Michael Winterbottom is careful not to paint Henderson as a hero, but rather the most ordinary of people forced to react against a heartless international community. With a cast that also includes Kerry Fox, Woody Harrelson and Marisa Tomei, “Welcome To Sarajevo” is a different approach to the war genre - one in which no one involved is morally black or white.

results.title: We of the West Riding
results.creator_credit: Ralph Keene, Greenpark Productions and Ken Annakin
results.brief_description: Yorkshire, its people, factories and wild moorland scenery. We are shown the country in which the Bronte sisters were born and its influence on their famous novel. Finally the chorus of the Chapel Choir sings the Hallelujah Chorus from Handel’s “Messiah”.

results.title: Wayne's World
results.creator_credit: Penelope Spheeris, Lorne Michaels and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: A hilarious spoof where teenagers Wayne Campbell (Mike Myers) and Garth Algar (Dana Carvey) take on a sleazy TV executive (Rob Lowe) after his offer of a huge contract to tape their late night cable access show. After starting at the network it quickly becomes apparent that the road to the big time is hardly what it seems. At first a cause for celebration, Wayne and Garth’s progress to public success soon threatens the philosophy of genuine fun and enjoyment the two promote, and threatens Wayne’s attempts to win over rock musician Cassandra (Tia Carrerre). A non-stop comedy with a sincere twist, this film is tightly scripted by Myers and Bonnie and Terry Turner and can be well appreciated at many levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Penelope Spheeris, Lorne Michaels and Paramount Pictures

results.title: Wanda
results.creator_credit: Barbara Loden and Foundation for filmmakers
results.brief_description: A remarkable one-off from Elia Kazan’s wife. Shot in 16mm and blown up to 35mm, it’s a subtly picaresque movie about the wanderings of a semi-destitute but aimless American woman. Directing herself, Barbara Loden manages to make the character convincing in her directionless amorality, yet gradually sympathetic and even heroic. Essentially a road-movie with an existentialist backbone, the film depicts Wanda drifting into desultory relations with a bank robber, to whom she becomes attached despite his unpredictable temper. But Wanda botches everything and fails to deliver the getaway car after getting lost in a traffic jam. The story continues with our last glimpse of her back on the road, being picked up in a bar. Similar in feel to other contemporary films, “Two-Lane Black Top” and “Killing of A Chinese Bookie”, “Wanda” refuses to provide explanation or judgement of its characters and delivers a picture of both intimacy and tragedy. A neglected masterpiece of American independent film-making. Regrettably the director/star produced nothing else before her untimely death from cancer.
